error.signature: Error [ERR_WORKER_UNSERIALIZABLE_ERROR]: Serializing an uncaught exception failed

verdict.summary: A worker thread crashed with an error that could not be serialized and sent back to the parent thread via the structured clone algorithm.

dead_ends.action: Wrapping the entire worker in a try-catch without handling the error event on the parent
dead_ends.why_fails: Uncaught exceptions in worker threads are not caught by try-catch in the parent; you must listen for the 'error' event on the Worker instance

dead_ends.action: Restarting the worker in an infinite loop without addressing the root cause
dead_ends.why_fails: Creates a crash loop that consumes resources and masks the underlying bug

workarounds.action: Add proper error handling in the worker and serialize errors before throwing
workarounds.how: In the worker file, wrap logic in try-catch and use parentPort.postMessage({error: err.message}) instead of letting exceptions propagate

workarounds.action: Listen for 'error' and 'exit' events on the Worker instance in the parent
workarounds.how: worker.on('error', (err) => { /* handle */ }); worker.on('exit', (code) => { if (code !== 0) /* restart or log */ });

leads_to.condition: when the worker crash is caused by excessive memory usage

preceded_by.condition: when system memory pressure causes worker instability

frequently_confused_with.distinction: ERR_WORKER_UNSERIALIZABLE_ERROR means the worker threw an error that cannot be cloned, while worker OOM means the worker exceeded its heap memory limit
